newsitem.title: USA: Women, old, minorities help Clinton win Florida.
newsitem.headline: Women, old, minorities help Clinton win Florida.

text.p: President Bill Clinton's decision to fight the Republicans head on in Florida paid off when he became the first Democrat for 20 years to win the state.
Two factors with a touch of irony helped him carry the day, analysts said.
Women trying to balance jobs and home duties voted for a man dogged by allegations of marital infidelity.
And old folk who have flocked to Florida for a retirement in the sun rejected the 73-year-old Republican challenger Bob Dole in favour of the younger Clinton.
Support from working-class families and minorities was also crucial. Clinton took 47 percent of the vote against Dole's 43 percent, the first Democrat victor since Jimmy Carter in 1976.
Clinton had worked hard on Florida voters, spending $8 million from his war chest and making many campaign forays here.
He plunged into Miami's Little Havana, bastion of the conservative Cuban American community, and promised environmentalists he would help them save the Everglades.
"Dole had a problem with the ladies," Bob Joffe, an analyst at Mason Dixon Political Media Research, told Reuters.
"Women are in the work force and have responsibilities at home. They don't have a hell of a lot of patience with a candidate who they suspect doesn't understand what they are going through," he said.
The other important voting block was working-class families, Joffe said -- "alienated, normally apathetic but concerned about the economy".
"This time they went for Clinton or (Ross) Perot."
Clinton had successfully convinced older voters that a Republican adminstration would threaten their Medicare health benefits, drawing accusations from the Dole camp that he was using scare tactics.
Dole also campaigned relentlessly in the state, promising to slash taxes and assailing perceived flaws in Clinton's character. But it fell on deaf ears.
Minorities and immigrants bolstered Clinton's support. He was the overwhelming choice of blacks, with nine out of 10 voting for him.
"He helped my country," said Velius Prince, 47, of Miami Shores, a naturalised citizen from Haiti. "Clinton's not just president of the United States. He's the president for all over."
Although Dole won among Cuban American voters with 44 percent, Clinton won a 43 percent wedge in a community that by tradition is staunchly right-wing.

The 13 percent gain reflected that a younger generation of Cuban Americans is less obsessed with how a U.S. government deals with Cuban President Fidel Castro, while their parents were impressed by a tougher line Clinton has taken on their nemesis.
Gov. Lawton Chiles said the battle for Florida had been so crucial that Clinton reckoned if he won here the election was over.
Chiles said that when he called the president to say he had won, "he said I could turn out the lights".
But Joffe said the vote was as much against Dole as a sign of Clinton's popularity. The Miami Herald said many south Floridians who voted for Clinton did so grudgingly.
"His convictions seemed too elastic, his platitudes ("a bridge to the future") too contrived and the character-related charges leveled against him too plausible," it said.
